definition: Financial penalty imposed by federal regulator for GLBA violation. Penalty amounts vary based on violation severity
organization_owner: cooperation and prior violations. Authority limits: up to $100
version: 000 per institution violation and up to $10
key_features: Per GLBA Section 505 (15 USC 6805), civil monetary penalty is financial penalty assessed against institution or individual for GLBA violations. Penalty authority: FTC for non-banks; Federal Reserve for state member banks; OCC for national banks; FDIC for state non-member banks; NCUA for credit unions; CFPB for large institutions. Penalty not fixed; varies by case; adjusted for inflation annually. Factors: severity of violation, number of individuals affected, entity size, cooperation level, history of violations, remediation efforts, harm caused. Civil proceeding (not criminal); burden of proof: preponderance of evidence; administrative proceeding or federal court.
column11: All financial institutions subject to GLBA; individuals in violation roles; all institution types; applies to Financial Privacy Rule, Safeguards Rule, Pretexting Prevention, Breach Notification Rule violations
column12: Regulator enforcement authority: FTC for non-banks; Federal Reserve for state member banks; OCC for national banks; FDIC for state non-member banks; NCUA for credit unions; CFPB for large institutions; Enforcement staff brings cases; Administrative law judge for proceedings
column13: GLBA Section 505 (15 USC 6805 et seq.); 12 CFR 314.5 (breach notification); Regulator penalty authority; FTC Act Section 5; Dodd-Frank Act (CFPB); Inflation adjustments annually
column14: Active enforcement tool; penalties assessed in many cases; trend toward higher penalties; breach notification rule heightened focus; CFPB UDAAP enforcement growing; penalties increasing for repeat violators
column15: Penalty Authority: $100,000 per institution per violation; $10,000 per individual per violation; other statutes may differ; each day of violation counts as separate violation; multiple violations from single incident. Severity Assessment: intentional violation more severe than reckless which is more severe than negligent; knowing violation most serious. Scope of Impact: number of individuals affected significantly increases penalty; breach of 1 million customers much higher than 1,000; number of systems affected; geographic scope. Duration: longer violation duration equals higher penalty; repeated violations over time; continuous non-compliance. Prior Violation History: prior GLBA violations increase penalty; similar violations increase more; clean compliance history favors lower penalty; pattern most serious. Cooperation Level: cooperation with investigation reduces penalty; responsive to information requests; timely remediation efforts. Remediation Actions: swift remediation; comprehensive fixes; control improvements; training implementation; cooperation in remediation affects favorably. Negligence versus Intent: negligence lower; reckless intermediate; intentional most serious; knowledge of violation and failure to correct is serious. Harm to Consumers: actual identity theft; actual fraud; financial loss to consumers; reputational harm; number harmed is multiplier. Entity Size: large institution violation equals higher absolute dollar penalty; small institution lower dollars; asset size, revenue, customer count considered. Egregiousness: extremely serious violation higher penalty; deliberate hiding serious; priority on business over security serious; indifference serious. Regulatory Priorities: enforcement priorities affect penalty emphasis; breach notification compliance equals higher penalties; data security focus equals higher safeguards penalties. Mitigating Factors: prompt remediation after discovery; strong historical compliance; employee error not policy; reasonable reliance on counsel; systemic issue identified and fixed; security investments post-incident. Aggravating Factors: deliberate violation; hiding violation; failure to disclose; obstruction; profit over compliance; size of violation; harm to vulnerable populations; continued violations after warning. Penalty Calculation: Investigation phase; Finding of Violation; Penalty Proposal by enforcement staff; Settlement Negotiation between parties; Administrative Proceeding if no settlement (hearing before ALJ, evidence presentation, decision); Appeal to commission/board; Federal Court FTC litigation. Penalty Collection: Payment deadline typically 30 days; payment methods; installment plans if agreed; if non-payment: wage garnishment, asset seizure, federal court enforcement, liens. Consent Order Context: civil penalty amount agreed in settlement; payment deadline specified; consequences of non-payment stated. Reported Penalties: FTC reports major penalties publicly; press release; case description; settlement terms; deterrent effect. Examination Impact: post-enforcement examination verifies compliance; monitors remediation; continued oversight; future penalties affected if violations recur. Actual Cases: Equifax (2017) $700 million breach penalty, massive data breach, security failures; AOL (2005) $1.25 million Privacy Rule violation, inadequate safeguards; H&R Block/TaxACT (2011-2013) multi-million settlements privacy violations; LabMD $4.85 million medical identity theft risk; Capital One (2019) $100 million data breach, 100 million customers affected. Penalty Trends: Penalties increasing over time; breach notification rule increased focus; CFPB UDAAP enforcement growing; penalties for service provider non-oversight; inadequate incident response. Deterrent Effect: Penalties deter violator from future violations; deter similar institutions; emphasize compliance importance; justify regulatory enforcement; signal regulatory priorities; demonstrate authority; affect institutional security investment decisions. Institutional Impact: Financial Impact: significant penalty; affects profitability; shareholder questions; insurance implications; reputational damage; Operational Impact: remediation costs; staffing changes; operational disruptions; business model changes; service limitations; Regulatory Impact: heightened scrutiny; examination frequency increases; enforcement action on record; future enforcement more likely; settlement terms require monitoring. Relationship to Other Penalties: Separate from cease and desist order (financial versus prohibition); separate from consent order requirements (affirmative obligations); both may be imposed together; criminal penalties if applicable are separate. Defense Challenges: burden of proof preponderance of evidence (lower standard than criminal); institution may challenge violation proof or penalty reasonableness; Appeal to federal court with appellate review standard; substantial evidence review; arbitrary and capricious review. Settlement Value: Cost-benefit analysis; cost of litigation versus settlement; risk of higher penalty if litigation fails; certainty of settlement amount; timing and finality. Insurance: Cyber liability insurance may cover some penalties (varies by policy); investigation costs; remediation costs; not all defense costs; coverage limits apply. Recidivism: Repeat violations increase subsequent penalties dramatically; prior penalty not defense but aggravating factor; institution knowledge of requirement from prior penalty increases seriousness. Enforcement Discretion: Regulator exercises discretion in bringing case, penalty amount, settlement offer, monitoring; case-by-case approach; priorities vary by administration. Public Policy: Penalties justified by consumer harm prevention, regulatory deterrence, compliance incentives, public welfare protection, financial system stability, reputational effects on compliant institutions.

definition: Formal regulatory order requiring institution to cease violating GLBA and take affirmative corrective actions. Issued by regulator through administrative proceeding or federal court injunction. Order may be voluntary (consent) or mandatory (contested after hearing).
official_description: Under GLBA Section 505 and banking regulator enforcement authority, cease and desist order is formal regulatory order directing institution to cease violation and take corrective actions. Order prohibiting specific conduct; ordering specific remedial actions; injunctive relief in legal form. Administrative Order issued by regulator; may be consent order (negotiated, voluntary) or contested order (after hearing, mandatory). Federal Court Injunction issued by federal court; results from litigation; may be temporary restraining order (TRO), preliminary injunction, or permanent injunction. Violation Examples: unauthorized information sharing, inadequate safeguards, privacy notice failure, breach notification failure, pretexting, failure to implement required controls.
applicable_to: Financial institutions subject to GLBA; any violation type; applies to privacy violations, safeguards violations, pretexting violations, breach notification failure, unauthorized practices; prevents repetition
organization_owner: Issuing regulator: FTC for non-banks; Federal Reserve for state member banks; OCC for national banks; FDIC for state non-member banks; NCUA for credit unions; Federal court if litigation; Enforcement staff drafts order; General Counsel reviews; director/commissioner approves; Board may review
version: GLBA Section 505 (15 USC 6805 et seq.) enforcement authority; FTC Act Section 13(b) injunction authority; Banking regulator statutes (Federal Reserve Act, National Bank Act, Bank Holding Company Act, Federal Credit Union Act); Administrative Procedure Act for administrative proceedings; Federal Rules of Civil Procedure for court injunctions
status: Active enforcement tool; common in significant violations; appears in most major enforcement actions; consent orders more common than contested orders; federal court injunctions less common; monitoring required; subject to examination
key_features: Cease and Desist Language: IT IS ORDERED that [Institution Name] shall cease and desist from violating [specific GLBA provision]. Specific Prohibitions: specific practices ordered to cease; example cease sharing customer NPI with non-affiliated third parties without consent. Affirmative Obligations: specific actions institution must take; examples implement encryption per GLBA standards, establish incident response plan, notify affected customers, conduct risk assessment, implement multi-factor authentication. Compliance Timeline: immediate begin right away, or specific deadline (30 days, 90 days), phased implementation (Phase 1 60 days Phase 2 120 days), graduated compliance showing progress. Monitoring Requirements: annual compliance report to regulator, quarterly reporting if serious issues, third-party assessment (independent audit), testing results documentation, remediation verification, access to institution books and records by regulator. Order Duration: temporary order 15-30 days if TRO, preliminary injunction lasts during litigation, consent order typically 2-3 years monitoring, permanent injunction ongoing until modified, monitoring extends as needed if compliance issues. Compliance Procedures: compliance verified through regulator examination, independent auditor, institution self-certification with documentation, reporting requirements, frequency of reports, content of reports. Contested versus Consent Orders: Consent Order negotiated settlement, institution agrees to order, avoids hearing, admission/denial language often neither, penalty specified, compliance plan agreed; Contested Order after hearing before ALJ, institution challenges violation, evidence presented, ALJ decides, order issued, potentially higher penalty if litigation lost. Hearing Procedures: institution right to hearing, notice of charges, time to respond, hearing before ALJ, evidence presentation, witness testimony, cross-examination, ALJ decision, written decision with findings, appeal to commission/board. Compliance Plan: detailed action plan with timeline, responsible parties, milestones, success metrics, third-party assessment if required, board approval. Third-Party Assessment: independent auditor or consultant evaluates compliance, provides report to regulator, auditor qualifications, independence requirement, annual or periodic assessment, SOC 2 or ISO 27001 audit reports. Board Oversight: board responsible for compliance, board reports, budget approval, resource allocation, executive accountability, regular updates to board committee. Order Modification: order may be modified if circumstances change, compliance demonstrated, regulator agrees, process written request with justification, regulator approval, modified order issued. Release from Order: after compliance period if compliant order released, institution no longer under order, monitoring ceases, no ongoing reporting. Non-Compliance Consequences: violation of order triggers contempt proceeding, civil or criminal contempt possible, penalties, additional enforcement action, order modification more stringent, removal of officers if applicable. Injunctive Relief Federal Court: TRO (Temporary Restraining Order) lasts maximum 14 days, prevents irreparable harm, expedited procedure, no hearing required, ex parte possible; Preliminary Injunction lasts during litigation, plaintiff proves likelihood of success, irreparable harm, balance of equities, public interest, hearing required, appeals possible; Permanent Injunction issued in final judgment, continues indefinitely, prevents ongoing violation, appeals possible. Status Quo: order preserves status quo, prevents changes pending hearing, prevents damage pending litigation, preliminary injunction maintains during case. Scope of Injunction: broad all aspects of violation or narrow specific conduct, specific language required, clarity for enforcement, enforcement procedures. Violation of Order Enforcement: motion for contempt, civil or criminal, penalties up to $1,000 per day in some cases, imprisonment possible for serious violations, other enforcement actions (asset seizure). Relationship to Penalty: separate from civil penalty (both may be imposed), penalty is financial, order is behavioral/procedural, order enforces compliance, penalty sanctions violation. Public Announcement: regulator publishes enforcement action, case name, institution name, violation, settlement/order terms, public knowledge, precedent, deterrent effect. Examination After Order: post-enforcement examination, verify order compliance, monitor remediation, continued oversight, examination frequency may increase, follow-up exam more frequent. Examples: Bank Privacy Violations order to establish privacy notice program, implement opt-out procedures, train staff, annual certification. Safeguards Violations order to conduct risk assessment, implement encryption, implement MFA, endpoint protection, quarterly vulnerability scanning, annual penetration testing, annual certification. Breach Notification Violations order to establish incident response plan, notify FTC within 30 days of future breaches, maintain communication, annual testing of response plan.

definition: Negotiated agreement between institution and regulator resolving alleged GLBA violation. Institution agrees to cease conduct
organization_owner: submit to monitoring. Avoids adversarial hearing while binding institution to compliance. Most GLBA enforcement actions resolved through consent orders.
version: Under GLBA and banking regulator enforcement authority, consent order (settlement agreement, stipulated order) is negotiated resolution of alleged violation. Agreement negotiated between regulator enforcement staff and institution counsel; executive-level approval required; board approval often needed. Process: regulator brings enforcement action, institution receives notice, opportunity to respond, escalation to formal enforcement if needed, pre-settlement negotiation begins. Settlement Options: full settlement (resolves all allegations), partial settlement (resolves some), settlement with consent order, settlement with civil penalty, settlement with cease and desist, combination of remedies.
status: Financial institutions with alleged GLBA violations; parties seeking to resolve matters; institutions willing to cooperate and settle; applies to all regulator types; small institutions to large banks; all violation types
key_features: Institution: Chief Executive Officer for authority, Chief Counsel (General Counsel) negotiates, Chief Compliance Officer advises, Chief Risk Officer advises; Regulator: Enforcement staff negotiates, counsel for institution and regulator, director/commissioner for approval, Board/commission may review significant settlements
column11: GLBA Section 505 (15 USC 6805 et seq.) authority to settle; FTC Act Section 5 authority; Banking regulator settlement authority; Administrative Procedure Act (APA) consent order procedures; Federal Rules of Civil Procedure for federal court settlements; settlement authority varies by regulator
column12: Common enforcement approach; more frequent than contested litigation; most enforcement actions resolved by consent order; faster than adversarial proceeding; provides certainty for both parties; subject to monitoring and examination
column13: Consent Order Content: Respondent Identification institution name, individual if applicable, clear identification. Recitals background on investigation, allegations summary, facts establishing violation, legal basis. Admission/Denial of Violation no admission of violation (standard in settlements), no denial (neither admits nor denies), allows settlement without establishing precedent, denies nothing by settling. Consent to Order respondent consents to order, waives hearing, waives rights to contest, knows consequences, settles matter. Civil Penalty penalty amount, payment deadline typically 30 days, payment method, non-payment consequences. Remediation Requirements detailed plan with specific actions, implementation timeline, responsible parties, milestones, verification procedures, third-party assessment if required. Safeguards Implementation institution commits establish comprehensive information security program per GLBA standards, nine safeguard elements, risk assessment, design and implementation, monitoring and testing, training, vendor oversight. Compliance Plan detailed plan showing how remediation achieved, timeline with milestones, responsible parties, resources allocated, board oversight, progress reporting. Monitoring and Reporting duration typically 2-3 years, annual or quarterly reporting, reporting contents specified, third-party assessment annual or quarterly, auditor qualifications specified, documentation required. Certifications CEO/CFO certification of compliance, board resolution approving plan, annual certifications of compliance, officer attestation of accuracy. Board Engagement board must approve compliance plan, receive regular reports, ensure resource allocation, maintain accountability, review remediation progress, ensure effectiveness. Audit Rights regulator retains rights conduct audits, request documents, conduct examinations, assess compliance, interview personnel, unannounced visits. Confidentiality often order is public, FTC publishes, banking regulators may publish major settlements, contents matter of public record, no confidentiality agreements preventing regulator action. Cost-Benefit Language Respondent acknowledges that benefits of compliance will outweigh the costs, order language addressing compliance burden, institution agrees burden justified. Scope of Remediation narrow (specific violation) or broad (institution-wide improvements), depends on violation extent, regulator judgment. Technology Requirements specific technologies required (encryption, MFA, monitoring) or performance standards (standards-based instead of prescriptive), either approach acceptable. Vendor Management if vendor breach requires vendor oversight procedures, vendor audit rights, service provider agreement requirements, vendor compliance verification. Third-Party Assessment independent auditor/consultant evaluates compliance, provides report to regulator, typically annual minimum, SOC 2 or ISO 27001 audit reports, qualified professional (CPA, security professional). Successor Entity if acquired order extends to successor, if divested order releases divested entity if no violations, order covers combined entity if acquired. Order Duration and Release monitoring period defined 2-3 years typical, at conclusion if compliant order released, if non-compliant monitoring extends, escalation possible. Modification Procedures order may be modified if circumstances change, compliance achieved faster, regulator agrees, process written request with justification, regulator approval, modified order issued. Board Reporting board receives quarterly or annual compliance reports, examination findings, remediation status, budget impacts, strategic implications, escalation of issues. Settlement Value Institution analysis cost of settlement penalty plus remediation, cost of litigation plus risk of higher penalty, certainty versus risk, timing and finality value, settlement often less costly than litigation risk. Regulator Analysis regulator gets compliance achieved, violation remedied, deterrent effect, certainty of outcome, efficient use of enforcement resources, public settlement discouraging similar violations. No Precedent Advantage consent order with no admission regulator still gets settlement, other institutions cannot cite admission as precedent, institution avoids admission, both parties benefit. Criminal versus Civil separation consent order civil only, separate criminal proceeding possible, civil settlement does not preclude criminal prosecution, both civil and criminal possible but rare together. Reputational Impact Institution: settlement public, brand/reputation affected, customer/investor concerns, employee impact, media coverage for major settlement. Regulator: enforcement action signals regulator authority, deterrent effect on industry, regulatory priorities shown. Stakeholder Communication communicate to customers (assurance of compliance), employees (training/changes), board/investors (regulatory matter resolved), public statement if media interest. Performance Monitoring monitor implementation of compliance plan, remediation progress, control effectiveness, violation prevention, incident history, compliance program maturity. Benchmarking Against Standards compliance measured against GLBA requirements, industry best practices, regulatory guidance, examination standards, comparable institution practices. Escalation Triggers escalation if non-compliance discovered, remediation delayed, failed testing, control failures, new violations, monitoring extended, additional enforcement action possible. Future Violations if subsequent violation occurs prior settlement not defense, prior violation aggravates new violation, penalties for repeat violations much higher, compliance history favors defendant in settlement negotiations. Examination After Settlement post-settlement examination verifies compliance with order, monitors remediation, enforcement findings, issue resolution, follow-up examination within 12 months typical for serious cases. Institutional Cooperation Impact settlement terms reflect cooperation with investigation, responsiveness, remediation efforts, transparency, cooperation reduces penalty/terms severity. Budget Impacts significant remediation costs system improvements, consulting, auditing, training, opportunity cost, affects profitability, affects executive compensation decisions. Insurance and Coverage cyber liability insurance may cover some settlement costs (varies by policy), investigation costs, remediation costs, insurance may not cover penalties (depends on policy).
